author: By Peter Libbey
title: When a Two-Week Stay Becomes a Permanent Move
description: Madeline Hollander and Samuel Parker, who met four years ago, forged a close relationship while quarantined at his home in Los Angeles.
content: Samuel Parker gave Madeline Hollander a piece of jewelry before they had gone on even a single date. It was an earring she had lost at La Caverna, a club in the Lower East Side of Manhattan, where they were both celebrating the opening of the 2019 Whitney Biennial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Love in the Blitz’ and ‘Sunny Days’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: LOVE IN THE BLITZ: The Long-Lost Letters of a Brilliant Young Woman to Her Beloved on the Front, by Eileen Alexander. (Harper, 496 pp., $17.99.) Imagine how Jane Austen “might have witnessed the Blitz, and you have a sense of this wonderful book,” our reviewer, Thomas E. Ricks, raved about these recently discovered letters from a future translator of Georges Simenon’s detective novels to her lover in the R.A.F.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lois Smith Brady
title: A Spiritual Meeting in the Sand and a Wedding There, Too
description: Emily Arnold and Youssef Ait-Khouya met while riding camels in Morocco.
content: On the morning of April 24, Emily Arnold and Youssef Ait-Khouya walked over the dunes at Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park outside Kanab, Utah, chose a spot to get married and began accessorizing it. They laid down Moroccan rugs and pillows, set up a portable table and decorated it with vases of flowers, a tea set and Moroccan lanterns. The surrounding dunes were continually changing shape because of the near-constant wind. A sign inside the park reads: “When you left your car in the parking lot, you left stability behind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Great Ideas From Our Readers
description: Tell us how you’ve used The Times to teach. We love to publish ideas from our readers.
content: Do you use The New York Times in your classroom? Whether you’re a teacher, parent, coach, librarian, tutor, counselor, adviser, administrator or even a student, we want to hear about your idea for teaching or learning with The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Mmmm, Tastes Like America
description: Sno-balls in sweaty New Orleans. Fudge cake on the Outer Banks. Spicy fruit on a Los Angeles street corner. This is what an American summer tastes like.
content: The Blizzard was an instant hit when Dairy Queen introduced it in 1985. “Dairy Queen’s Blizzard Is Hot,” The New York Times reported the next year, crediting the delicacy with boosting the company’s stock price and sales of mix-ins, like Heath bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: Reading Dan Frank, Book Editor and ‘Champion of the Unexampled’
description: Alan Lightman, Janna Levin and others recall the editor who shaped their work and a literary genre. Plus, more reading recommendations in the Friday edition of the Science Times newsletter.
content: Summer is basically here, and now is the moment to find a book to fall into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Touching the Void’ Review: Choices That Shape a Life on the Edge
description: This Bristol Old Vic production, based on the harrowing story of the British mountaineer Joe Simpson, tracks the spiral of decisions behind human exploits.
content: Many movies, books or shows are metaphorical slogs. The play “Touching the Void” is about a literal one: the slow, agonizing crawl of the British mountaineer Joe Simpson as he tried to return to his base camp after sustaining a gruesome injury on an Andes peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Sexual Abuse Lawsuit Splits the Gucci Family
description: One of Guccio Gucci’s great-granddaughters went public with alleged wrongdoing, and now her younger sister is involved too.
content: For the last few months, scenes from Lake Como in Italy, where Ridley Scott is filming “The House of Gucci,” the movie about the murder-for-hire of Maurizio Gucci by his wife, have trended on social media. Viewers have cooed over the clothes and the stars, Adam Driver and Lady Gaga, while the family itself has lodged protests against what a Gucci scion Patrizia Gucci said was “stealing the identity of a family to make a profit, to increase the income of the Hollywood system.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Decluttering for a Renovation
description: Before the contractor can get started on demolishing my kitchen, I have to clear out the things I don’t need. But everyone needs a melon scooper, right?
content: Of all the random objects residing in my kitchen drawers, the truffle shaver is probably the most absurd. I’ve cooked with fresh truffles once, long before I lived in this house. I bought this slim, metal blade at the now closed Dean & Deluca in SoHo with my husband before he was my husband. We were living in our first apartment together in Brooklyn and had the good fortune of spare time and money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Syra Madad
title: Why Are So Many of My Fellow Health Workers Unvaccinated?
description: Medicine must address vaccine holdouts among us. Here's how.
content: In April of last year, I along with my entire family — my husband, my three children, in-laws and at least one of our four home health aides — came down with Covid-19. The domino effect of household transmission was like a spark that set our house on fire. It was one of the most frightening experiences of my life — and I am an infectious disease epidemiologist who responded to the Ebola outbreak in 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and David Poller
title: Capitol Riot, Memorial Day, French Open: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Christopher Stone, Who Proposed Legal Rights for Trees, Dies at 83
description: A law review article he wrote in 1972 kick-started a worldwide movement to grant nature the same rights enjoyed by human beings.
content: Christopher D. Stone, who in 1972 made what seemed a whimsical argument — that forests and rivers should have rights in the eyes of the law — and in the following decades found his work galvanizing environmental lawyers in the United States and launching a global movement to grant nature the legal status of personhood, died on May 14 at an assisted living facility in Los Angeles. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Democrat or Republican, You Probably Love the Post Office
description: A new bipartisan bill could help fix the U.S. Postal Service.
content: Last year, in the midst of a presidential election campaign and a pandemic, the U.S. Postal Service was politicized by President Donald Trump and his administration as had never been done before. Critics accused the postmaster general, Louis DeJoy, of making changes to mail delivery to increase Mr. Trump’s chances of re-election, a charge he vehemently denied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Kingston
title: She Put Her Unspent Love in a Cardboard Box
description: And for more than two decades, her daughter has been taking it out.
content: In the back of my closet is a small cardboard chest with brass handles and latches that has followed me to every new address; it’s the first thing I find a place for as the moving truck pulls away. An old sticker on the bottom says it was purchased at Ross for $26.99. The only remaining contents are three wrapped presents marked in my mother’s tidy cursive: “Engagement,” “Wedding” and “First Baby.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: When a Good First Impression Lingers
description: Christine Sun and Michael Hurwitz first met in 2015 at a party at the University of Virginia. They reconnected months later through Tinder.
content: When Christine Sun and Michael Hurwitz first encountered each other, at a party hosted by the University of Virginia business school in 2015, they talked for a few minutes and both came away from the conversation a little surprised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: JD Logistics, the delivery arm of the Chinese e-commerce giant, gains in its I.P.O.
description: The listing raised more than $3.1 billion, showing an appetite for offerings by Chinese internet firms even as the tech industry faces heightened scrutiny from Beijing.
content: JD Logistics, a supply chain unit of JD.com, the big Chinese internet retailer, raised more than $3.1 billion in a share listing in Hong Kong on Friday, the latest Chinese company to raise money in a record-breaking year for the city’s stock exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Clifford Krauss
title: A Big Climate Problem With Few Easy Solutions: Planes
description: The airline industry might not be able to reduce greenhouse gas emissions for decades because most solutions are not yet viable.
content: The worst of the pandemic may be over for airlines, but the industry faces another looming crisis: an accounting over its contribution to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Giggs
title: There Is So Much You Don’t Know About Being a Fly
description: In “Super Fly” Jonathan Balcombe explores the world of the most annoying creature, moving beyond the buzz and drone.
content: SUPER FLYThe Unexpected Lives of the World’s Most Successful InsectsBy Jonathan Balcombe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Traveling This Memorial Day Weekend? Pack Patience.
description: As Americans hit the road for the holiday, they may find things crowded, more expensive and with less staff to keep things running smoothly.
content: Last year, for the first time in 20 years, AAA, the automobile owners group, declined to put out its annual Memorial Day travel forecast as the surging coronavirus pandemic kept many people close to home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: The Eerie Familiarity of a Melbourne Lockdown
description: In Victoria, a return to the drudgery and uncertainty of strict Covid regulations.
content: It’s all so eerily familiar. The gray weather and afternoon sunsets. The anxious wait for the day’s numbers. The obsessive checking of exposure sites. The rumors of restrictions, followed by the reality of lockdown. The kids home from school. Birthday parties canceled, holidays postponed. The dreary, fearful, resigned uncertainty of it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India is in talks to obtain 50 million doses of the Pfizer vaccine.
description: The supplies would deliver a boost to the country’s slowing inoculation campaign, but officials are still considering the drug company’s demands for indemnity.
content: The Indian government is in talks with Pfizer to obtain 50 million doses of the company’s coronavirus vaccine starting this summer, but is still considering the drug manufacturer’s demand for indemnity from costs related to severe side effects, officials have said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing puts off 787 deliveries again to provide more information to the F.A.A.
description: The latest disruption comes as the troubled aerospace manufacturer seeks to overcome delays and concerns about several of its planes.
content: Boeing said Friday that it was providing the Federal Aviation Administration with extra information related to inspections of its 787 Dreamliner, further delaying deliveries of the plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five New Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: From haunted houses to killer dolls, these frightful offerings will keep you entertained, or up all night.
content: “A Quiet Place Part II” and “Spiral: From the Book of Saw,” are hogging the horror movie spotlight in theaters at the moment. But on streaming, these five under-the-radar horror films should be elbowing their way onto your watch list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: obtrusive
description: This word has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: Note: This is our final Word of the Day for the 2020-21 school year. The feature will start again in September.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cat’s ’Sup
description: Andrew Ries opens our solving weekend.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Even though I enjoyed it, this was a tough one for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Lloyd
title: So, You Want to Mingle Outdoors This Summer?
description: Going to Disney World this summer? Or to your niece’s sixth birthday party? Here’s how to do it safely.
content: During spring break last month, Monica Gandhi tested her confidence in coronavirus science. She and her two unvaccinated children stood in a packed crowd near a well-known bridge in Austin, Texas, to enjoy watching the emergence at dusk of thousands of Brazilian free-tailed bats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Pride Said Gay Cops Aren’t Welcome. Then Came the Backlash.
description: Just as L.G.B.T.Q. visibility reached a new peak, splinter groups are re-examining the annual parade. Is Pride too corporate? Should police officers be allowed to march? Is it a revolution, or is it a party?
content: It was two weeks before the start of Pride month, and the organization that runs New York’s Pride march was fighting about cops. The leadership had just announced that officers could no longer take part in the march, including a contingent of L.G.B.T.Q. officers that has marched in uniform since 1996.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Small Earthquakes Rattle Lake Tahoe Area
description: Damage was minimal, but seismologists are concerned that a recent series of quakes could trigger a big one, spawning a 30-foot tsunami in the lake.
content: At least six small earthquakes, including one with a preliminary magnitude of 4.2, shook the Lake Tahoe, Reno and Carson City area early on Friday, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: Scenes From a Mogul’s Marriage or: The Troubling Fourth Act of Bill Gates
description: The collapse of the world’s most philanthropic marriage makes us take a hard look at the image the couple tried to project.
content: Three years ago, Bill and Melinda Gates answered a range of personal questions in their annual letter — a rare peek into what kept one of the world’s most powerful couples together.
source.name: The New York Times

content: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

title: Canadian Lawmaker Is Exposed on Camera for a Second Time
description: After appearing naked during a virtual House of Commons session in April, a member of Parliament said that he urinated while on video this week.
content: OTTAWA — For the second time in just over a month, a member of Canada’s Parliament has apologized for exposing himself during a virtual legislative session.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: At Naval Academy Graduation, Harris Focuses on Strengthening a ‘Fragile’ World
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, the school’s first female commencement speaker, used her speech to address some of the Biden administration’s most urgent challenges.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Kamala Harris achieved another first for women on Friday when she addressed the graduating class of the United States Naval Academy, becoming the first female commencement speaker in the school’s nearly 175-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: Behind the Jim Crow Curtain
description: “Opal’s Greenwood Oasis” and “Unspeakable” restore the often-elided history of a prosperous, close-knit Black community on the eve of its destruction.
content: The city of Tulsa, Okla., unleashed hell on earth 100 years ago this month when it deputized part of the mob that looted and burned the prosperous African-American community of Greenwood. When the carnage subsided, perhaps as many as 300 Tulsans lay dead. Thirty-five square blocks of homes, churches and schools — along with a storied business district known as Black Wall Street — had been systematically torched and reduced to ash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spain Issued ‘Equality Stamps’ in Skin Tones. The Darker Ones Were Worth Less.
description: The campaign, marking the anniversary of George Floyd’s murder, aimed to oppose “an unfair and painful reality that should not exist.” To many, it only made things worse.
content: MADRID — A new campaign by Spain’s postal service that was intended to condemn racism has backfired and ended up offending many people with a series of stamps in skin tones — the lighter the shade, the more valuable the stamp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Anthony Davis and the Lakers Are Back on Their Feet
description: In Los Angeles, a star absorbs a few blows as he delivers shot after shot, leading the Lakers past the Suns.
content: LOS ANGELES — It was not an especially pleasant night of basketball for Anthony Davis. Productive? Yes. Pleasant? No.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Nike Says It Ended Deal With Neymar Amid Investigation of Sexual Abuse
description: Nike said that Neymar, the soccer superstar, had refused to cooperate with an investigation into “credible allegations of wrongdoing” made by one of the company’s employees.
content: Nike ended its sponsorship agreement with the Brazilian soccer superstar Neymar last year after he refused to participate in an investigation of an accusation that he had sexually assaulted a Nike employee, the company confirmed Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: AMC shares whipsaw as retail investors swarm.
description: Retail traders piling into AMC aim, in part, to force losses on hedge funds that have bet against it.
content: Shares of AMC, the movie theater chain, surged more than 30 percent in early trading Friday before erasing all of those gains, as the whirlwind trading of small investors returned.By the end of the day on Friday, AMC was down 1.5 percent. But, including Friday’s drop, AMC shares jumped 116 percent this week.The trading is reminiscent of the GameStop frenzy in January. One of the aims of the retail traders is to push up a company’s share price to force losses on hedge funds that have bet against the stock in what is called a short squeeze. At the end of 2019, before AMC became a “meme stock” darling like GameStop, the video game retailer, and Blackberry, the phone company, the share price for AMC was about $2.GameStop slid 12 percent on Friday, but climbed about 26 percent for the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Summer’s here.
content: Welcome. At Home was born in March 2020, as part of The Times’s effort to help readers lead full and cultured lives at home during the coronavirus pandemic. We replaced the Travel section in the Sunday newspaper with an At Home section and launched this newsletter, hoping to be of service, to offer ideas for how to pass the time and make sense of a world that seemed, too often, wholly senseless.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Was the ‘She-cession’ Worse in the U.S. Than Germany?

content: — Matthias Doepke, an economist at Northwestern, on what’s causing the global “she-cession”

title: San Jose Gunman Detested Workplace Long Before Rampage, Police Say
description: The gunman, a maintenance worker at a transit agency in Silicon Valley, killed nine of his colleagues years after federal officials uncovered a notebook with his complaints.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The first reports of gunfire at the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority light rail yard near downtown San Jose, Calif., came in at 6:34 a.m. on Wednesday, about half an hour into a morning shift.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Friends’ Reunion Is Censored in China, Cutting BTS and Lady Gaga
description: Cameos by Justin Bieber, Lady Gaga and the K-pop group BTS mysteriously disappeared from the special when it aired on Chinese streaming sites. Online, fans suspected censorship.
content: In China, the reunion episode of “Friends” was all about grudges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: For ‘F9,’ Making Stunts That Stick
description: The concept of electromagnets factor heavily into the new film, creating the impression of cars stuck together and leaving stacks of wreckage in a way only the “Fast and the Furious” films know how.
content: They’ve launched cars into the sky from the backs of planes. They’ve jumped cars through buildings in Abu Dhabi, they’ve raced cars on sheets of ice and pitted them against submarines. What’s next for the filmmakers of the “Fast and Furious” series, a franchise that, for 20 years, has been a magnet for audiences?
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Yang’s New York Ties Are Questioned, He Cites Anti-Asian Bias
description: Mr. Yang, who is seeking to make history as the city’s first Asian American mayor, says anti-Asian sentiment has crept into the campaign.
content: Andrew Yang, a son of Taiwanese immigrants and a leading candidate for mayor of New York City, took on issues of race and identity in extraordinarily personal terms on the campaign trail this week, seeking to reframe some criticisms of his candidacy as questions of his Americanness.

author: By Chris Cameron and Mark Walker
title: Tribes to Confront Bias Against Descendants of Enslaved People
description: The Choctaw Nation and the Muscogee (Creek) Nation in Oklahoma said they would consider granting citizenship to the Freedmen.
content: With pressure growing from the Biden administration, two Native American tribes in Oklahoma have agreed to consider reversing their policies of denying citizenship to descendants of Black people who were enslaved by them before the Civil War.

title: Lobbyist Closely Tied to N.Y. Assembly Speaker Draws Federal Scrutiny
description: The public corruption unit of the U.S. attorney’s office in Manhattan is examining Patrick Jenkins, a former aide to Carl Heastie and a top state lobbyist.
content: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed a top New York lobbyist closely tied to Assembly Speaker Carl E. Heastie and sought records from at least two of his clients and a state agency in recent weeks, according to people with knowledge of the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colette Coleman
title: The Case for Paying All Teachers Six Figures
description: The pandemic gave us a newfound appreciation for educators. Now let’s compensate them accordingly.
content: During the Covid-19 pandemic, debates over school closures and student safety grew in an understandable way. But this back and forth left no oxygen for robust conversation about lagging salaries for K-12 educators — an issue that was finally getting the attention it deserved before Covid hit. But now that each week brings more vaccine jabs and more news of school districts fully reopening in the fall, it’s time for this issue to get back in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Does the Devil Wear Prada in Indiana?
description: Discovering Broadway, a nonprofit founded in 2019, has brought actors and writers to the state for weeklong retreats to workshop movies-turned-musicals.
content: CARMEL, Ind. — What do the performers Christy Altomare and Corey Cott do during a weekend in this midsize Central Indiana city in between workshops for a Broadway-aimed musical?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: A judge orders the appointment of a ‘special master’ to review devices the F.B.I. seized from Giuliani.
description: The review would decide if prosecutors, who are investigating whether Mr. Giuliani broke lobbying laws, can access material from devices the F.B.I. found in a search of his home.
content: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday ordered the appointment of a so-called special master to review whether materials seized from Rudolph W. Giuliani’s apartment and office during an F.B.I. search in April are protected by attorney-client privilege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I Want to Invest in My Wardrobe. Help!
description: A reader wonders what they can buy that lasts.
content: All I can say is: You’re a lot more forward-thinking than I was at your age. And more important, what you are thinking about is what may be the single most effective thing any of us can do when it comes to fashion and climate change: laying the building blocks of a sustainable wardrobe — that is, one that lasts over time and is not disposable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Hollywood Bowl Is Now on Plan C: Filling All 18,000 Seats
description: With regulations changing by the week, the Bowl went from planning a modest reopening for sparse crowds to weighing vaccine requirements to planning to return at full capacity.
content: LOS ANGELES — They are playing ball at Dodger Stadium, with all 56,000 seats on sale for games beginning next month, and not an inch of social distance between them. Across the country, Radio City Music Hall in New York is flinging open its doors and selling 5,960 shoulder-to-shoulder seats to the vaccinated in a decidedly indoor setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: The U.S. heads into another pandemic summer, but this time with optimism.
description: Ahead of Memorial Day weekend, one epidemiologist said, “We’re kind of at the beginning of the end” of the fight against the coronavirus.
content: Ahead of Memorial Day a year ago, many officials in the United States had canceled parades and banned crowded gatherings. The country was on the cusp of recording 100,000 deaths from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Still Here and Still Queer: The Gay Restaurant Endures
description: Many have closed in a time of growing inclusion and more fluid sexual identities. But in several places around the country, they remain anchors of safety and community.
content: Scott Frankel’s favorite memories of New York gay restaurants aren’t about food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Alex Hay, Comeback Painter
description: In the first survey of an artist who took a 30-year hiatus from the art world, his special brand of realism remains strong even as it becomes more abstract.
content: A half-century on, Alex Hay’s giant paint-and-canvas homages to items usually found in stationery stores continue to amuse and amaze. His 1965 painting “Legal Pad” lives up to its title, with the pale yellow of the paper and the pale blue of the delicate horizontal lines running edge to edge. It might almost be the real thing, except that, at nearly 8 feet tall, it looms. Its combination of precise realism and outsize scale encapsulates the conundrum of Hay’s art: It is both commanding and modest, stately and slightly comic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Will the Next Space-Weather Season Be Stormy or Fair?
description: As another 11-year cycle of solar activity begins, scientists debate how violent our stellar friend is likely to be.
content: The big news about the sun is that there is no big news. We are blessed, astronomers like to say, to be living next to a “boring star.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Dayan
title: Real Peace Depends on Recognizing Israel’s Right to Exist
description: Accepting Israel's right to exist is a prerequisite for a lasting peace.
content: At a news conference recently President Biden made a statement that might have seemed unremarkable: “Let’s get something straight here,” Mr. Biden said. “Until the region says unequivocally, they acknowledge the right of Israel to exist as an independent Jewish state, there will be no peace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Errol Morris
title: Errol Morris: What We Believe About Beliefs
description: What you think you know is probably wrong — and that’s putting it nicely.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we believe? You can read more essays by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: Russia Appears to Carry Out Hack Through System Used by U.S. Aid Agency
description: Senior Democrats said the latest attack, ahead of President Biden’s meeting with his Russian counterpart, demanded a stronger response.
content: WASHINGTON — A newly disclosed effort by Russian intelligence to hijack the email system of a United States government agency prompted leading Democrats on Friday to urge stronger action against Moscow for accelerating cyberattacks ahead of President Biden’s summit next month with President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: At Long Last, a New Rail Tunnel Under the Hudson River Can Be Built
description: After four years of stalling by the Trump administration, officials in Washington approved the $11.6 billion project for federal funding.
content: For five years, the plan to build a second pair of rail tunnels between New York City and New Jersey has been deemed one of the most critical infrastructure projects in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: Was 1971 the Year ‘Music Changed Everything’?
description: How would 1974 feel about that? Or 1965? A new eight-part documentary on Apple TV+ is the latest salvo in the record geek’s eternal debate.
content: Everything changed with the music of 1971. No, wait. It was 1973. Check that — 1974 was the year, except it was music, film and television, but only in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 7 Podcasts to Soothe Your Back-to-Normal Anxiety
description: These shows will help you to navigate whatever complex feelings you’re having about the world reopening, and ease you back into society at your own pace.
content: We have collectively lived through a global trauma that’s going to take years, maybe even decades, to process. With vaccination rates in the United States rising and infection rates plummeting, most of the Covid-19 restrictions we’ve become used to are disappearing, while all the forbidden fruits we’ve learned to live without — from indoor dining to air travel to large gatherings — are once again within our grasps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wolpe
title: The Jewish History of Israel Is Over 3,000 Years Old. That’s Why It’s Complicated.
description: From the Torah, through the exile, Jews have always looked to Jerusalem.
content: My first visit to Israel was when I was 12 years old. The group was led by my father, a rabbi from Philadelphia. We had been invited to participate in an archaeological dig near the city of Beit Shean, in the country’s north, near the Jordan River Valley. Soon after we arrived, one of my friends happened upon a pottery shard, really an ostracon, a fragment with writing on it. The archaeologist on site said something to him in Hebrew. My father translated: “He said you are the first person to hold that in over 2,000 years.”

content: During its 20 year run, “Law & Order” cast five different actors in the role of Manhattan district attorney, a rate of turnover that feels like science fiction given that, in reality, four people have been elected to the office in 83 years. content: An article on Tuesday about allegations of workplace misconduct by Michael Larson, a longtime money manager for Bill Gates, included an incorrect description of a letter reporting an encounter between Mr. Larson and the bicycle shop manager who accused him of harassment.
